subject: Re: [junit] Re: chosing between jmock and easymock for mocks?
msgSnippet: ... It s the other side of the coin: either you prefer generating the method, but have to pay for /having/ to generate it, or you prefer not to have to
messageBody:
Jon Skeet wrote:
> > > And there is also the issue of code completion when
> > > defining expectations. With JMock, it does not work, you
> > > have to rely on text completion features.
> > > With EasyMock, it works like a charm.
> >
> > I do admit that this is a shortcoming, but I don't find that annoying
> > when I use jMock. In fact, in an odd way, if I find I really
> > want code completion when defining fakes or expectations, then perhaps
> my
> > interface is too complex. :)
>
> This raises an issue which I don't *think* I've seen mentioned here.
>
> I find that there's a bit of a benefit when writing test code with
> EasyMock (either version) in that after typing in what I want to be
> called before it exists, I can then ask Eclipse to generate all the
> methods for me, in both the interface and the class. The tests really do
> drive the code - it's only when a test requires a method to be present
> that it gets put in the interface, because I don't end up writing the
> interface declarations by hand in the first place. (Of course, I add
> documentation and might change the parameter names later, but that's a
> different matter.)
>
> Just a small benefit, but I thought I'd mention it...
>
> Jon (a very happy EasyMock user)

It's the other side of the coin: either you prefer generating the
method, but have to pay for /having/ to generate it, or you prefer not
to have to generate it, but have to pay for having to type it by hand. I
think it's strictly a personal taste thing: the price is the same.
